questions.text: Clearance of apoptotic cells by professional and nonprofessional phagocytes is called
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 46

Efferocytosis

  • Apoptotic bodies may also become coated with natural antibodies and proteins of the complement system, notably C1q, which are recognized by phagocytes.
  • Numerous ligands induced on apoptotic cells serve as “eat me” signals and are recognized by receptors on phagocytes that bind and engulf these cells.
  • This process of apoptotic cell phagocytosis is called efferocytosis; it is so efficient that dead cells disappear, often within minutes, without leaving a trace
  • Efferocytosis is performed by macrophages and to a lesser extent by other ‘professional’ phagocytes (such as monocytes and dendritic cells) and ‘non-professional’ phagocytes, such as epithelial cells.
  • Defective efferocytosis underlies a growing list of chronic inflammatory diseases, cystic fibrosis & bronchiectasis, COPD, rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which is not immune transfusion reaction

choices.text: White infarcts are seen in small intestine
Red infarction are seen in tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
Red infarcts are seen in arterial occlusions
White infarcts are seen when flow is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about infarcts
questions.solution:
Infarcts are classified according to color and the presence or absence of infection; they are either red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic) and may be septic or bland.

Red infarcts are seen in

  • With venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • In loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • In tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine) that allow blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • In tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow – Option B
  • When flow is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 133

questions.text: 50 year old male presents with stroke due to brain haemorrhage. his autopsy revealed following, diagnosis
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page. 1278

The clue of pink material surrounding blood vessels should have given the clue of amyloid. The image inset shows IHC for AB (Amyloid Beta)

Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy

  • Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is an almost invariable accompaniment of AD; however, it can also be found in brains of individuals without AD.
  • In CAA consists of β amyloid deposits in the blood vessels and is primarily seen in the leptomeningeal and cortical (rather than basal ganglia and white matter) vessels
  • The amyloid in CAA is predominantly comprised of Aβ40 (compared to AB 42 seen in Alzheimers)
  • Amyloid deposition can weaken the vessel wall and lead to hemorrhage; as a result, many individuals with CAA have evidence of numerous small hemorrhages within the brain (“microbleeds”) that can be visualized by various imaging method

Black arrow shows pink acellular material around vessels and blue arrow show IHC for AB amyloid suggestive of amyloid angiopathy

questions.text: A 23-year-old Afro-Caribbean woman presents with symptoms of anemia. She has also suffered from swollen painful joints. Her serum iron is low, TIBC low, TS low with microcytic hypochromic cells. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page. 659

This is typical profile of ACD with the history of swollen joints, the possible etiology should be a long standing arthritis

Three pathophysiologic mechanisms have been identified:

  • Slightly shortened RBC survival, thought to be due to increased hemophagocytosis by macrophages, occurs in patients with inflammatory diseases.
  • Erythropoiesis is impaired because of decreases in both erythropoietin (EPO) production and marrow responsiveness to EPO.
  • Iron metabolism is altered due to an increase in hepcidin, which inhibits iron absorption and recycling, leading to iron sequestration.

Lab diagnosis

  • Microscopy - Microcytic or normocytic anemia (more of normocytic)
  • Anemia is initially normocytic and then can become microcytic.
  • Serum iron and transferrin are typically decreased, while ferritin is increased. (Ferritin being an acute phase reactant(
  • Treat the underlying disorder and consider recombinant erythropoietin.

questions.text: A 6 month old child presented with bleeding from umbilical cord stump...his BT is normal, PT AND PTT is normal. What test will you do next to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page. 667-669

Bleeding from Umbilical coed stump and with normal clotting factor tests – should suspect and work up for Factor XIII deficiency. The test to detect factor XIII deficiency is Clot solubility test.

Clot Solubility Test

  • The plasma samples [patient and control] are clotted by the addition of an excess of calcium and incubated at 37°C for 30 minutes.
  • An alternative approach involves clotting the plasma with Thrombin and saline.
  • The clot is removed and placed in 5M urea and incubated for 24 hours at either room temperature or 37°C.
  • If the clot has dissolved this suggests FXIII deficiency (F XIII is clot stabilisation factor) and a formal FXIII assay should be undertaken.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about covishield
questions.solution:
Reference – AstraZeneca Booklet.

Covi-Shield

  • The vaccine, which is known as Covishield, is made from a weakened version of a common cold virus (known as an adenovirus) from chimpanzees. It is not made from attenuated COVID-19 strains
  • It has been modified to look more like coronavirus - although it can't cause illness.
  • When the vaccine is injected into a patient, it prompts the immune system to start making antibodies and primes it to attack any coronavirus infection.
  • The vaccine is administered in two doses given between four and 12 weeks apart. It can be safely stored at temperatures of 2C to 8C, about the same as a domestic refrigeration

questions.text: Which of the following soft tissue tumors is wrongly matched with its cytogenetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page. 1209.

The list of translocations in sarcoma has been repeatedly asked in the recent exams. There are a few must know amongst them which are highlighted in the below table. (The must know includes which are used in routine diagnosis in real life)

questions.text: A middle aged immune compromised man came with history of fever and breathlessness. CT showed a middle lobe lesion with infiltration. Lung biopsy from the lesion is as below.
questions.solution:
Lung Pathology by Byran. Page. 355

The clue here is immunocompromised, but all the above options can happen in immunocompromised persons. Now in the image you can identify intranuclear blue inclusions.  The only amongst the above option can cause intranuclear basophilic inclusion is CMV

Diagnostic clue for above. 

  • CMV - Intranuclear blue inclusion (can have intracytoplasmic also) – Classical OWL EYE need not be present always
  • Cryptococcus - The clear capsule surrounding the organism is the clue. The capsule is positive for Mucicarmine stain.
  • HSV – Multinucleated, ground glass inclusion
  • Fungal – Spores or Hyphae will be demonstrated (Aspergillus – branched hyphae)

questions.text: The below biopsy is from bone of a 50 year old patient who came with pathological fracture. The patient was evaluated and was found to have mutation in SQSTM1 gene. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page. 1183

Mosaic appearance of bone is classical of Pagets disease.

 Etio-pathogenesis of Pagets disease

  • Mutations in the SQSTM1 gene that increase NF-κB activity and thus enhance osteoclast activity.
  • Activating RANK mutations and inactivating OPG mutations account for some cases of juvenile Paget disease.
  • Chronic infection of osteoclast precursors by measles or other RNA viruses

questions.text: Which of these sarcomas show lymphatic spread
questions.solution:
Sarcomas showing lymphatic spread -  Mneumonic - SCARE

  • Synovial sarcoma
  • Clear cell sarcoma
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Epitheloid

questions.text:
Which of these relations between chronic inflammatory states and cancer is correct
A. IBD and colorectal cancer
B. Sjogren syndrome and MALT lymphoma
C. Lichen sclerosis and vulval cancer
D. H pylori and gastric carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 315

Chronic Inflammation and Cancer

  • Persistent infections within the host induce chronic inflammation.
  • Leukocytes and other phagocytic cells induce DNA damage in proliferating cells, through their generation of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species that are produced normally by these cells to fight infection.
  • These species react to form peroxynitrite, a mutagenic agent. Hence, repeated tissue damage and regeneration of tissue, in the presence of highly reactive nitrogen and oxygen species released from inflammatory cells, interacts with DNA in proliferating epithelium resulting in permanent genomic alterations such as point mutations, deletions, or rearrangements.
  • Indeed, p53 mutations are seen at frequencies similar to those in tumours in chronic inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease

questions.text: A 30 year old female came with abdominal pain and adnexal mass. Her Ca 125 and LDH was marginally elevated and CA 19-9 was not elevated. She was operated and specimen was sent for histopathology. Below is the image of the gross and microscopic picture. Your diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1024

Dysgerminoma:

Dysgerminomas account for about 2% of all ovarian cancers.

  • They may occur in childhood, but 75% occur in the second and third decades.
  • Some occur in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism.
  • Most of these tumors have no endocrine function.
  • A few produce elevated levels of chorionic gonadotropin and may have syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells on histologic examination

Gross features:

Usually unilateral (80% to 90%), most are solid tumors ranging in size from barely visible nodules to masses that virtually fill the entire abdomen.

On cut surface they have a yellow-white to gray-pink appearance and are often soft and fleshy. They are said to resemble cerebral cortex

Microscopy:

  • On histologic examination the dysgerminoma cells are dispersed in sheets or cords separated by scant fibrous stroma
  • Nests of tumor cells separated by fibrous stroma with T lymphocytes
  • Large vesicular cells with well defined cell borders, cleared cytoplasm containing glycogen and central nuclei
  • Early carcinomatous differentiation:30+ mitoses per 10 high power fields, may worsen prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following Acts as Morphogen in embryonic development(i.e. influences the pattern of tissue differentiation) & promotes cell migration.
questions.solution:
Scatter factor

  • HGF is produced by stromal cells, and stimulates epithelial cell proliferation, motility, morphogenesis and angiogenesis in various organs via tyrosine phosphorylation of its receptor, c-Met.HGF was originally discovered as a mitogen of adult rat hepatocytes
  • Scatter factor (SF) was first identified as a human embryonic fibroblast -derived protein that enhances motility of renal tubular cells this motogenic activity of SF was abolished by adding anti-HGF antibody. So it was concluded that scatter factor is actually HGF

questions.text: A study of peripheral blood smears shows that neutrophil nuclei of women have a Barr body, whereas those of men do not. The Barr body is an inactivated X chromosome. Which of the following forms of RNA is most likely to play a role in Barr body formation?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 5

Lyonisation

  • Xist(X-inactive specific transcript) is a non-coding RNA on the X chromosome of the placental mammals that acts as a major effector of the X-inactivation process
  • The human Xist RNA gene is located on the long (q) arm of the X chromosome.
  • XIST, which is transcribed from the X chromosome and plays an essential role in the physiologic X chromosome inactivation that occurs in females.
  • XIST itself escapes X inactivation but forms a repressive “cloak” on the X chromosome from which it is transcribed, resulting in gene silencing.
  • X-chromosome inactivation is the transcriptional silencing of one X chromosome in female

questions.text: 56 year old male presents with fever, gum bleeding and repeated infections. On examination, he has leucocytosis. on peripheral smear, cells showed cup like invaginations. Mutation present in AML having blasts with 'cup-like' nuclear invaginations
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 592

AML with Cup like Nuclei

  • AML cases with cuplike nuclei represent an uncommon morphological variant of AML highly associated with FLT3-ITDand NPM1
  • To qualify cup like nuclei - 10% of blasts with prominent nuclear invaginations representing at least 25% of the nuclear area, the presence of cuplike nuclei in AML represents a distinctive morphologic finding that can be used to prioritize the molecular workup of AML cases

choices.text: a, b and d are true, c is false
a, b, c, d all are true
Only a AND b ARE TRUE

questions.text:
34 year old male presenting with acrocyanosis. especially in winters. his peripheral blood smear shows following. which of the following is true about disease shown below

a. It is due to IgM antibodies
b. The antigenic determinant is i/I
c. Antigenic determinant is P antigen
d. It shows donath Landsteiner antibodies
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 649

The picture shows large aggregates of RBC’s -  agglutination seen only in Cold agglutinin AIHA. (see table below)

A must know table regarding Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia

questions.text: A proponent of workout touts its contribution to longevity, but he controls his dietary caloric content so that his body mass index is <22. This lifestyle promotes increased insulin sensitivity and glucose utilization. He fully expects to live longer because he has read that caloric restriction prolongs life. In this man, which of the following intracellular substances will most likely mediate the effect of calorie restriction upon increased longevity?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 68

Sirutins

  • Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases.
  • There are at least seven types of sirtuins in mammals that are distributed in different cellular compartments and have nonredundant functions designed to adapt bodily functions to various environmental stresses, including food deprivation and DNA damage.
  • Sirtuins are thought to promote the expression of several genes whose products increase longevity.
  • These include proteins that inhibit metabolic activity, reduce apoptosis, stimulate protein folding, and counteract the harmful effects of oxygen free radicals.
  • Sirtuins also increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism, and may be targets for the treatment of diabetes.

questions.text: At the site of a surgical incision, endothelial cells elaborate vascular endothelial growth factor. There is sprouting with migration of endothelial cells into the wound to establish new capillaries. Which of the following intracellular proteins is most important in facilitating movement of endothelial cells?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 106

Angiogenesis involves sprouting of new vessels from existing ones and consists of the following steps

  • Vasodilation in response to nitric oxide and increased permeability induced by vascular endothelial growth  factor (VEGF)
  • Separation of pericytes from the abluminal surface and breakdown of the basement membrane to allow formation  of a vessel sprout.
  • Migration of endothelial cells toward the area of tissue injury - mediated by actin
  • Proliferation of endothelial cells just behind the leading front (“tip”) of migrating cells.
  • Remodeling into capillary tubes.
  • Recruitment of periendothelial cells (pericytes for small capillaries and smooth muscle cells for larger vessels) to  form the mature vessel.
  • Suppression of endothelial proliferation and migration and deposition of the basement membrane.

choices.text: Transcription factor mutations that interfere with normal myeloid differentiation
Mutation of signaling proteins that result in constitutive activation of pro-growth/survival pathways
Mutations of gene that regulate or maintain epigenome

questions.text: All these are example of driver mutations in AML except
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 592

  • Different translocations and chromosomal rearrangements create chimeric genes that encode fusion proteins that interfere with transcription factors and bock maturation of myeloid cells.
  • AMLs with t(15;17) have activating mutations in FLT3, a receptor tyrosine kinase that transmits signals that mimic normal growth factor signaling 
  • AMLs associated with IDH1 and IDH2 mutations that create oncometabolite 2-hydroxyglutarate affect epigenome.
  • Mutations of TP53 or genes that regulate p53 adds poor prognosis in AML

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has noted breast secretions for the past month. She is not breastfeeding and has never been pregnant. She has not menstruated for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no abnormal findings. MRI of the brain shows a 0.7-cm mass within the Sella turcica. Which of the following additional complications is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1070

Sella turcica tumour + Galactorrhea -  Most likely diagnosis is prolactinoma.

  • Prolactinomas are more common than other hormone secreting pituitary adenomas.
  • In addition to her galactorrhoea and infertility, this patient also may have decreased libido, and her amenorrhea is secondary to the excessive prolactin secretion.
  • Microadenomas might not have pressure effects on surrounding structures such as optic chiasm, but they can be discovered because of their hormonal effects.
  • Acromegaly results from a growth hormone secreting pituitary adenoma in an adult. Cushing disease occurs when there is an ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma. A thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)−secreting pituitary adenoma is uncommon, but it could account for elevated levels of T4 and TSH in a hyperthyroid patient.

choices.text: Predisposes to testicular germ cell neoplasms especially seminoma
Most common site of arrest of testicular descent is inguinal canal
Thickening of basement membrane of spermatic tubules is seen in early stages
Sertoli cells are spared and therefore relatively prominent.

questions.text: A 6-month male infant went for routine vaccination, his pediatrician found bilateral scrotal sac empty in the infant, which is a false statement regarding cryptorchidism
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 967

Cryptorchidism Histology

  • Early on, thickening of the basement membrane of the spermatic tubules is seen
  • Subsequent loss of spermatogonia leaves the tubules with only Sertoli cells.
  • The scarred tubules may appear as dense cords of hyaline connective tissue associated with a concomitant increase in interstitial stroma.
  • Leydig cells are spared and therefore appear relatively prominent.


Testicular atrophy in cryptorchidism. The tubules show Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis. There is thickening of basement membranes and an apparent increase in interstitial Leydig cells.

questions.text: An experiment involves factors controlling wound healing. Skin ulcerations are observed, and the factors involved in the healing process are analysed. Which of the following factors is most likely to be effective in promoting angiogenesis?
questions.solution:
Mechanisms of Angiogenesis.

The process of angiogenesis involves several signaling pathways, cell–cell interactions, ECM proteins, and tissue enzymes.

  • VEGFs, mainly VEGF-A, stimulate both migration and proliferation of endothelial cells, thus initiating the process of capillary sprouting in angiogenesis.
  • VEGF promotes vasodilation by stimulating the production of NO and contributes to the formation of the vascular lumen.
  • Fibroblast growth factors (FGFs), mainly FGF-2, stimulate the proliferation of endothelial cells. They also promote the migration of macrophages and fibroblasts to the damaged area and stimulate epithelial cell migration to cover epidermal wounds.
  • Angiopoietins 1 and 2 (Ang 1 and Ang 2) are growth factors that play a r ole in angiogenesis and the structural maturation of new vessels. Newly formed vessels need to be stabilized by pericytes and smooth muscle cells and by the deposition of connective tissue.
  • The growth factors platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-β also participate in the stabilization process: PDGF recruits smooth muscle cells and TGF-β suppresses endothelial proliferation and migration and enhances the production of ECM proteins.

choices.text: It arises from parafollicular cells, or C cells
It is associated with MEN 2A or 2B
RAS plays an important role in its genesis

questions.text: Amyloid deposition is seen in the thyroid neoplasm of 34 year old female. On examination , the tumor shows plasmacytoid cells in the background of amyloid. Which of the following is not true about this tumor
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Medullary carcinoma Thyroid

  • Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine neoplasms derived from the parafollicular cells (C cells). They account for approximately 5% of thyroid neoplasms. Medullary carcinomas, like normal C cells, secrete calcitonin, the measurement of which plays an important role in the diagnosis and postoperative follow-up of patients.
  • Activating point mutations in the RET proto-oncogene play an important role in the development of both familial and sporadic medullary carcinomas
  • Microscopically, medullary carcinomas are composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles. Small, more anaplastic cells are present in some tumors and may be the predominant cell type. Amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma in many cases
  • In some instances, the initial manifestations are those of a paraneoplastic syndrome caused by the secretion of a peptide hormone (e.g., diarrhea due to the secretion of VIP, or Cushing syndrome due to ACTH)
  • Medullary carcinomas arising in the context of MEN-2B are generally more aggressive and metastasize more frequently than those occurring in patients with sporadic tumors or MEN-2A

questions.text: Which of the following translocations in multiple myeloma is associated with high risk?
questions.solution:
Ref. WHO Classification of Tumours of Haematopoietic and Lymphoid Tissues. Pg 245

Genetics is a powerful predictor of prognosis and has been combined with the ISS (R- ISS) to provide improved risk stratification.

  • Genetic risk stratification based primarily on FISH analysis stratifies cases into standard-risk, inter- mediate-risk, and high-risk categories
  • The most important genetic indicators of high-risk myeloma are deletion of 17p/TP53 sequences and t(14;16) and t(14;20).
  • Like any other neoplasm TP53 mutation makes the tumour behave badly by helping in acquiring more new mutations.

Risk stratification of Myeloma as per Mayo Classification (WHO)Q



Questions based on this table have been asked in previous AIIMS and JIPMER exams.

questions.text: Autophagy can be classified into the mentioned classes except one:
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 48
Depending on how the material is delivered, autophagy can be categorized into three types:

  • Chaperone-mediated autophagy (direct translocation across the lysosomal membrane by chaperone proteins).
  • Microautophagy (inward invagination of lysosomal membrane for delivery).
  • Macroautophagy (hereafter referred to as autophagy), the major form of autophagy involving the sequestration and transportation of portions of cytosol in a double membrane bound autophagic vacuole (autophagosome).

choices.text: Fat forty female is a risk factor
Seen in cases of hemolytic anemia
Most of the black stones are radiolucent

questions.text: A 25 year old with history of right hypochondrial pain and fever was operated and the specimen is as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the below pathology?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 875

The history is suggestive of acute cholecystitis.

Pigment gallstones are brown to black

  • Black pigment stones are found in sterile gallbladder bile and brown stones are found in infected large bile ducts.
  • Black stones contain oxidized polymers of the calcium salts of unconjugated bilirubin, small amounts of calcium carbonate, calcium phosphate
  • Brown stones contain similar compounds along with some cholesterol and calcium salts of palmitate and stearate.
  • Approximately 50% to 75% of black stones are radiopaque due to calcium salts

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT BH(1-4) MOLECULE
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 45

Proteins involved in Apoptosis

  • BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1 are the principal members of this group; they possess four BH domains (called BH1-4).
  • BAX and BAK are the two prototypic members of this group; they contain the first three BH domains (BH1-3).
  • Members of this group, including BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa, contain only one BH domain, the third of the four BH domains, and hence are sometimes called BH3-only proteins

questions.text: A 23 year old present with tense bulla over extremities. The histopathology is as below. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1162

The picture shows bulla separation. Any question with bulla look at the site of separation.

Above picture shows separation at the dermo-epidermal (Sub epidermal region)  - Diagnostic of Bullous pemphigoid

  • All vesiculobullous lesions starting with the word “pemphigus” show intraepidermal blisters which could be subcorneal, intraepidermal or suprabasal.
  • Among the pemphigus lesions, subcorneal blisters is seen in pemphigus foliaceus and suprabasal blisters seen in pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Bullous pemphigoid present with subepidermal blisters formed by the antibodies reaction against “bullous pemphigoid antigen” present in basement membrane.

choices.text: Loss of function mutation in PTEN

questions.text: A 20-year-old man's closest friends tell him he looks different now than a year ago, with coarse features. He bought new shoes with his usual size and they do not fit. A year later his 23-year-old brother has similar problems. Both of them have hyperglycaemia. Which of the following genetic alterations is most likely present in both brothers?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1071

Diagnosis in this patient is GN secreting pituitary adenoma.

Somatotroph Adenoma

  • Growth hormone (GH)-secreting somatotroph adenomas are the second most common type of functioning pituitary adenoma, and cause gigantism in children and acromegaly in adults.
  • The aryl hydrocarbon receptor–interacting protein (AIP) gene mutations account for a minority of growth hormone (GH)–producing pituitary adenomas, but may be present in younger persons in familial cases.
    Other mutaions associated with GH secreting adenomas - Protein kinase A, regulatory subunit 1α , GNAS, MEN1
  • Microscopy
    • Densely granulated somatotroph adenomas are composed of monomorphic, eosinophilic cells with granular cytoplasm and a large central nucleus with prominent nucleoli. The cells have diffuse, strong immunoreactivity for GH.
    • Sparsely granulated variants are composed of chromophobe cells with patchy, weak staining for GH and a characteristic paranuclear glossy inclusion known as a fibrous body, composed of intermediate filaments that stain for cytokeratin.

choices.text: Transforms to infiltrating squamous cell cancer in 50% cases
Associated with high risk HPV, especially HPV 16
Contains dysplastic squamous cells containing large hyperchromatic nuclei and lacking orderly maturation

questions.text: False statement about Bowen disease
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 965

Bowens Disease

  • Bowen disease most commonly affects the penile shaft and scrotum of older men.
  • At these sites, it appears as a solitary, thickened, gray-white, opaque plaque. In less common cases when it affects the glans, the lesion acquires a velvety red appearance.
  • Histologically, the lesion consists of dysplastic squamous cells containing large hyperchromatic irregular nuclei and lacking orderly maturation, mitoses, some atypical, are numerous.
  • In 10% of patients, Bowen disease gives rise to infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Some carcinogens interact preferentially with particular DNA sequences or bases and thus produce mutations that are clustered at hotspots
Aflatoxin B1- associated HCC tend to have P53 mutation
Aflatoxin B1- associated HCC tend to have beta catenin mutation

questions.text: True statements regarding mutational hotspot in chemical carcinogenesis
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 332

Aflatoxin and HCC

  • Because of their chemical structures, some carcinogens interact preferentially with particular DNA sequences or bases and thus produce mutations that are clustered at “hotspots” or that are enriched for particular base substitutions.
  • This phenomenon is illustrated by a mutational “hotspot” associated with exposure to aflatoxin B1, a naturally occurring agent produced by some strains of the mold Aspergillus
  • Aspergillus grows on improperly stored grains and nuts, and there is a strong correlation between the dietary level of this food contaminant and the incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Aflatoxin B1–associated hepatocellular carcinomas tend to have a particular mutation in TP53, a G:C→T:A transversion in codon 249 that produces an arginine-to-serine substitution in the p53 protein that interferes with its function.

questions.text: A 23yr old female presented to OPD with complaint of a papule on her left buttock for 1 week, biopsy revealed this histology, diagnosis
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1168

This shows a dome shaped papule with dimpled center and intracytoplasmic viral inclusions- Henderson Paterson bodies.

POX VIRUS

Largest pathogenic virus of vertebrates

Important pox virus are :

– Variola (causative agent of small pox)

– Vaccinia (Artificial virus which was used as small pox vaccine)

– Molluscum contagiousum

Molluscum Contagiosum

  • Usually seen in children and young adults.
  • Characterised by pink or pearly white nodules on skin which show large inclusion bodies called Molluscum bodies.( Henderson - peterson bodies) – can be seen on Tzank smears also
  • Viral inclusions are seen in the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum of skin biopsy
  • Virus can not be grown in eggs, tissues culture or animals

questions.text: 50 year old with pancytopenia with tear drop cells and splenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is used to grade the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 626

Always look at the history if a question like this is given. Making a diagnosis on HPE is tough.

Chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis

  • Clinical presentation: Splenomegaly
  • Peripheral smear examination: Pancytopenia, leukoerythroblastic blood film and tear drop cells
  • Bone marrow aspiration : There will be either “dry tap” or “bloody tap”
  • Bone marrow biopsy :
    • Prefibrotic phase: Hypercellular marrow spaces, with abnormal megakaryocytes in the form of clusters, immature forms, dysplastic forms noted.
    • Fibrotic phase : Increased reticulin fibres with streaming of hematopoietic cells, hypocellular marrow spaces, dysplastic megakaryocytes and dilated sinusoids

questions.text: Below is the picture of direct immunofluorescence (FITC) for IgG done on a kidney biopsy. Based on the results on this investigation, most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 911

  • IgG DIF interpretation - The above picture denotes a diffuse, linear 3+ staining of the GBM.
  • The only option which produces linear IgG is Good pasture syndrome

Anti – GBM induced nephritis:

  • The antibodies are directed against intrinsic fixed antigens that are normal components of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) proper resulting in a diffuse linear pattem of staining for the antibodies by immunofluorescence techniques.
  • This is the model of anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome) which is caused by antibodies against non-collagenous domain of the alpha 3 chain of collagen type IV

Other options:

  • Membranous glomerulonephritis – Granular positivity
  • SLE – Will have full house effect all the antibodies will be positive
  • Berger’s dieaser (IgA Nephropahty) – Shows IgA deposits not IgG

questions.text: Lynch syndrome is associated with cancer of the
questions.solution:
• Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder
  • It is also called as Hereditary non- polyposis colon cancer (HPCC) syndrome
  • It is caused because of defective DNA repair genes leading to microsatellite instability
  • There is increased chance of multiple cancers (colorectal area, endometrium, ovary stomach, ureter, brain, small intestine , hepatobiliary tract and skin)

choices.text: Characterised by neuroendocrine neoplasm in Pancreas, pituitary and parathyroid gland
Can cause medullary carcinoma and pheochromocytoma

questions.text: All of the following are true about MEN4 syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1131

MEN 4 syndrome - These patients have clinical features that phenocopy MEN-1 patients, but in contrast to that syndrome, harbor germline CDKN1B mutations, leading to reduced levels of the cell-cycle checkpoint protein, p27.

Below image gives a detailed manifestations of MEN syndrome

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to physician by his parents because of difficulty breathing for the past hour. The parents report noisy breathing and bluish discoloration of their son's lips. During the past 2 months, the patient has had several URTIs and poor weight gain. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 20th percentile for length percentile for weight. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Pulse is 160/min, RR= 40/min and BP = 80/55mmHg. Crackles are heard over both lung fields. A CXR shows B/L interstitial infiltrates. Intubation is performed and methylprednisolone is given. Methanamine silver staining of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid shows aggregates of 2-8 cysts with central spores. Serum IgA titers are decreased. Which is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 244

This patient’s current infection is caused by Pneumocystis Carinii (cysts with central spores on methanamine silver stain) suggestive of defect in cell-mediated arm of immune response. Since this patient also has decreased IgA, it suggests mixed T and B cell deficiency. Out of the options above, only defect in CD40 ligand (Hyper IgM syndrome) and thymic aplasia (part of DiGeorge syndrome) can cause both B and T cell deficiency. DiGeorge syndrome patients would also have facial dysmoprhism and hypocalcemia, thus effectively ruling it out.

Hyper-IgM Syndrome

  • In this disorder, affected patients have IgM antibodies but are deficient in IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies.
  • Mature B cells are present, but they are incapable of Ig class switching and affinity maturation, because of a defect in CD4+ helper T cells or an intrinsic B-cell defect.
  • Approximately 70% of individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome have the X-linked form of the disease, caused by mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26 that interfere with CD4+ helper T cell function.
  • Rest, the disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern - loss-of-function mutations involving either CD40 or activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), a DNA-editing enzyme expressed in B cells that is required for Ig class switching and affinity maturation.
  • The serum of persons with this syndrome contains normal or elevated levels of IgM but no IgA or IgE and extremely low levels of IgG. The numbers of B and T cells in the blood are normal.

questions.text: Immediately following a renal transplant a patient experiences hyperacute rejection as shown in the biopsy picture below. What is the pathogenesis of this process?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 236

Here u are seeing coagulative necrosis in kidney and fibrinoid necrosis in vessels , suggestive of hyperacute rejection

Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.

  • The preformed antibodies may be natural IgM antibodies specific for blood group antigens, or may be antibodies specific for allogeneic MHC molecules that were induced by prior exposure of the organ recipient to allogeneic cells through blood transfusions, pregnancy, or transplantation of another organ.
  • Immediately after the graft is implanted and blood flow is restored, the antibodies bind to antigens on the graft vascular endothelium and activate the complement system, leading to endothelial injury, thrombosis, and ischemic necrosis of the graft.
  • Hyperacute rejection is rare because every donor and recipient are matched for blood type, and potential recipients are tested for antibodies against the cells of the prospective donor, a test called a cross-match.

questions.text: which part of spleen is involved here?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis: Amyloidosis of spleen (sago spleen)

  • Tapioca like granules in the spleen – amyloid limited to splenic white pulp - Sago spleen
  • Wall of splenic sinuses and connective tissue framework of red pulp - Lardaceous spleen

questions.text: 50 year old person came with complaints of hematuria and abdominal mass. USG showed a mass in the kidney. Biopsy shows the below image with characteristic perinuclear halo and positive for hales colloidal iron. Your most probable diagnosis.?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 948.

Chromophobe RCC

  • Chromophobe carcinoma represents 5% of renal cell cancers and is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus.
  • On cytogenetic examination, these tumors show multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy.
  • Origin from intercalated cells of collecting ducts and have an excellent prognosis compared with that of the clear cell and papillary cancers.
  • Large tumor cells with fine eosinophilic granularity, peripheral accentuation of cytoplasm, perinuclear halo, wrinkled raisinoid nuclei, frequent binucleation and coarse chromatin (resembles koilocytes); still some classic chromophobe cells
  • DD - Oncocytoma

questions.text: A well defined coin like lesion in an elderly male with the below microscopic appearance diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 1158

Seborrheic keratosis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis

Clinical Features

  • Single or multiple, sharply demarcated pigmented lesion that protrudes above surface of skin
  • Appears to be stuck to skin
  • Soft, tan-black, 'greasy' surface

Microscopy

  • Acanthotic proliferations of small cuboidal keratinocytes without cytologic atypia
  • Usually has 'horn pseudocysts' (round intralesional cysts of loose keratin) – You can see them in the above image – cystic areas from the top
  • String sign: lesion extends to a uniform depth and one could draw a horizontal line parallel to the epidermal surface underlying the lesion
  • Typically, mounds of parakeratosis containing neutrophils and serum are present at the ostia of hair follicles (so-called follicular lipping).

questions.text: In renal biopsy of a 14 year old boy with nephritic syndrome, glomeruli are showing proliferation of mesangial cells with GBM thickening and mesangial cell interposition. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 918

Mesangial cell interposition and BM thickening is characteristic feature of mesagiocapillary GN (MPGN)

Features of MPGN on a renal biopsy -  Highlighted points are diagnostic and potential MCQ’s

  • The glomeruli are large and hypercellular. The hypercellularity is produced both by proliferation of cells in the mesangium and so-called endocapillary proliferation involving capillary endothelium and infiltrating leukocytes.
  • The glomeruli have an accentuated “lobular” appearance due to the proliferating mesangial cells and increased mesangial matrix
  • The GBM is thickened, and often shows a “double-contour” or “tram- track” appearance, especially evident in silver or PAS stains. This is caused by “duplication” of the basement membrane (also commonly referred to as splitting), usually as the result of new basement membrane synthesis in response to subendothelial deposits of immune complexes.
  • Between the duplicated basement membranes, there is inclusion or interposition of cellular elements, which can be of mesangial, endothelial, or leukocytic origin. Such interposition also gives rise to the appearance of “split” basement

questions.text: The 55 year old male was admitted in surgical ward for treatment of perforation. He has history of intake of antibiotics . On resection of intestine, the following characteristic finding was seen. What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 793

Microscopic image -   This shows Pseudomembranous colitis with volcano eruption exudates Pseudomembranous Enterocolitis

  • Pseudomembranous colitis is generally caused by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile and is also referred to as antibiotic-associated colitis or antibiotic-associated diarrhea
  • Toxins released by difficile cause the ribosylation of small GTPases such as Rho, leading to disruption of the epithelial cytoskeleton, tight junction barrier loss, cytokine release, and apoptosis.
  • Toxin-mediated cytoskeletal disruption in other cell types, particularly neutrophils, may also contribute to development of purulent pseudomembranes.
  • Microscopy - The surface epithelium is denuded, and the superficial lamina propria contains a dense infiltrate of neutrophils and occasional fibrin thrombi within capillaries.
  • Pathognomonic finding: Muco- purulent exudate that characteristically erupts from damaged crypts to form “volcano” lesions and coalesces to form pseudomembranes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with a history of an allogeneic bone marrow transplant (matched sibling donor) performed in a reference hospital due to acute myeloid leukemia one year before. The patient started having oral and skin lesions. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to rule out graft versus host disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 239

The diagnosis in this patient is GVHD - No blood test can identify a graft versus host reaction.GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically compromised recipients, and the transferred cells recognize alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues. The major clinical manifestations result from involvement of the immune system and epithelia of the skin, liver, and intestines.

  • A biopsy is a primary tool for the evaluation of suspected graft versus host disease.
  • The diagnosis can be complicated from other viral exanthems and drug eruptions and requires clinical correlation.
  • The most common cause of death in acute graft versus host reaction is overwhelming sepsis.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight loss, anemia, and fatigue. Blood work reveals a white blood cell count of 88,000 cells/mm3 and a hemoglobin of 9 grams/dL. He has a mildly enlarged spleen and liver. Cytogenetic testing reveals a chromosomal translocation resulting in a BCR-ABL1 fusion gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 948.

Chromophobe RCC

  • Chromophobe carcinoma represents 5% of renal cell cancers and is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus.
  • On cytogenetic examination, these tumors show multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy.
  • Origin from intercalated cells of collecting ducts and have an excellent prognosis compared with that of the clear cell and papillary cancers.
  • Large tumor cells with fine eosinophilic granularity, peripheral accentuation of cytoplasm, perinuclear halo, wrinkled raisinoid nuclei, frequent binucleation and coarse chromatin (resembles koilocytes); still some classic chromophobe cells
  • DD - Oncocytoma

choices.text: Should be given after 10 days of COVID infection
Non pregnant females can donate plasma
Weight of donors should be more than 50 kg
Donor should have IgG antibodies with titre 1:640 on ELISA

questions.text: What is NOT true about plasma therapy in COVID
questions.solution:
ICMR Guidelines.

Who can donate plasma

  • People who have tested positive for coronavirus and have recovered at least three weeks before donating and tested negative for Covid-19 twice.
  • People who are aged 18 or over, but not more than 60
  • People who weigh 50 kgs or more
  • Those who are fit and healthy
  • Both gender. Women who have never been pregnant
  • Should not have infections transmitted via blood (HIV, HBV, HCV)

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease dies of congestive heart failure. The brain at autopsy is shown in the image. This patient's brain exemplifies which of the following responses to chronic injury?
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 59

Clinically, atrophy is recognized as diminution in the size or function of an organ.

  • It is often seen in areas of vascular insufficiency or chronic inflammation and may result from disuse.
  • Atrophy may be thought of as an adaptive response to stress, in which the cell shuts down its differentiated functions.
  • Reduction in the size of an organ may reflect reversible cell atrophy or may be caused by irreversible loss of cells.
  • For example, atrophy of the brain in this patient with Alzheimer disease is secondary to extensive cell death, and the size of the organ cannot be restored.

questions.text: Working principle of thromboelastography?
questions.solution:
Ref. Practical Hemostasis and Thrombosis. Michell Makris.  Page. 220-223

Thromboelastography [TEG] provide global information on the dynamics of clot development, stabilisation and dissolution that reflect in vivo haemostasis. 

Principle of TEG

  • The TEGs analyser uses resonance-frequency viscoelastic measurement and a disposable all-in-one cartridge. 
  • The blood sample is suspended in a multi-channel cartridge and then exposed to external vibration (20–500 Hz).
  • As clotting proceeds and the blood sample changes state, the elasticity and resonant frequency increase. 
  • These changes in the clot-strength-specific resonance frequencies are detected by a photo-detector and converted into TEG-equivalent units. 
  • These are used to generate TEG tracings and which outline the viscoelastic change of the blood sample in real time. 

Uses

  • To help detect, manage and monitor hemostasis in cardiac surgery patients 
  • Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation of trauma patients
  • Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
  • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability

choices.text: Involved in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases
Glutathione dependent enzymes levels are increased
Injury decreases if intracellular ferrous levels decrease

questions.text: which of the following is not true about ferroptosis
questions.solution:
Ref: Robbins Pathology 10th edition. Page 47-48

Ferroptosis

  • Its triggered when excessive intracellular levels of iron or reactive oxygen species overwhelm the glutathione-dependent antioxidant defences to cause unchecked membrane lipid peroxidation.
  • The widespread peroxidation of lipids disrupts many aspects of membrane function, including fluidity, lipid-protein interactions, ion and nutrient transport, and signaling pathways.
  • The overall effect is the loss of plasma membrane permeability, which ultimately leads to cell death resembling necrosis.
  • The process can be prevented by reducing iron levels (hence its name).
  • Ultrastructurally, the most prominent features are the loss of mitochondrial cristae and ruptured outer mitochondrial membrane.
  • Ferroptosis has been linked to cell death in a variety of human pathologies, including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and stroke.
